item.title: Harvard University shares 7 tips to keep your memory sharp at any age - Hindustan Times
item.description:
7 Tips from Harvard University to Improve Memory at Any Age

Publication Date: December 20, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

As we age, keeping our memory sharp can become a challenge. Harvard University has provided seven tips to help individuals maintain and enhance their memory regardless of their age.

  • Keep Learning: Engaging in continuous education can help keep the brain active.
  • Use All Your Senses: Involve multiple senses during learning for better retention.
  • Believe in Yourself: Positive self-belief can aid memory improvement.
  • Economize Your Brain Use: Organize everyday items to avoid cluttering your memory.
  • Repeat What You Want to Know: Reinforce memory by repeating information aloud or in writing.
  • Space It Out: Use spaced repetition at intervals to enhance memory retention.
  • Make a Mnemonic: Use creative mnemonics to recall information more easily.
"Engaging the whole brain through varied learning strategies enhances memory retention." - Harvard University

In conclusion, by incorporating these simple yet effective tips, individuals of all ages can work towards maintaining and improving their memory function.

item.title: Can a cold actually turn out to be cancer? Signs you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
item.description:
Can a Cold Signal Cancer? Signs to Watch Out For

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

This article discusses the alarming possibility that some common cold symptoms might actually indicate more serious health conditions, including cancer. It emphasizes early detection as critical to preventing serious outcomes.

  • Chronic Cough: A cough lasting more than three weeks warrants immediate attention, as it may indicate lung or throat cancers.
  • Unintended Weight Loss: Sudden, unexplained weight loss can be associated with various cancers, highlighting the importance of monitoring such symptoms.
  • Recurrent Infections or Fevers: Frequent illnesses may signal an underlying cancer affecting the immune system, such as leukemia or lymphoma.
  • Persistent Fatigue: Extreme fatigue that does not improve with rest can be a sign of several cancers, including leukemia and colorectal cancer.
  • Difficulty Swallowing or Persistent Sore Throat: These symptoms often relate to throat or esophageal cancers and should not be ignored.

Consult a healthcare professional if symptoms last more than three weeks or worsen, as early diagnoses significantly improve treatment success rates.

Dr. Nishith Modi, HCG Cancer Centre-Vadodara: "A lot of colds can pass without causing panic, but there are certain warning signs that require vigilance for early detection."

Being proactive with lifestyle choices can help mitigate cancer risk factors, including quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, and participating in routine screening tests.

item.title: Exercise tips for seniors: Maintaining fitness beyond 70 - The Indian Express
item.description:
Exercise Tips for Seniors: Maintaining Fitness Beyond 70

Publication Date: December 2024 | Source: The Indian Express

This article emphasizes the importance of regular physical activity for seniors over the age of 70, outlining various types of exercises that can promote health and mobility.

  • Engagement in regular aerobic, strength, and flexibility activities is crucial for seniors.
  • The World Health Organisation recommends 150 minutes of moderate or 75 minutes of vigorous activity weekly for aerobic workouts.
  • Cardiovascular exercises that are suitable include swimming, cycling, and walking for about 30 minutes daily.
  • Strength training can include light weight training or bodyweight exercises such as squats and push-ups.
  • Yoga and stretching are important for improving mobility and reducing joint stiffness.
  • Balance exercises, like standing on one leg, are beneficial to prevent falls.
“Exercises for balance, such as standing on one leg, assist people avoid falls, which are a common concern for people in this age range.”

Maintaining a fit lifestyle beyond the age of 70 is not only possible but essential for overall health and well-being.

item.description:
3 Wellness Rules For December: Enjoy The Celebratory Season Nutritiously

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: The Health Site

This article discusses how to enjoy festive celebrations in December while maintaining a focus on health and nutrition. It offers simple wellness rules to help individuals navigate holiday indulgences without compromising their well-being.

  • Enjoy Feasts Responsibly: Exercise portion control during meals.
  • Take Care Of Heart Health: Incorporate healthy fats and reduce unhealthy fats in your diet.
  • Nourish Your Body: Opt for whole grains, vegetables, and fruits to start your day.
"Moderation is key... listen to your body's hunger and fullness cues to avoid overeating."

By following these wellness tips, individuals can enjoy the festive season with a balanced approach to eating and health.

item.title: Yemen faces a cholera crisis; Arabian Peninsula country accounted for 35% of global cholera cases as of December 1: WHO - Down To Earth Magazine
item.description:
Yemen faces a cholera crisis; Arabian Peninsula country accounted for 35% of global cholera cases as of December 1: WHO

Published on: 24 Dec 2024, 4:51 am

War-torn Yemen is suffering from a cholera epidemic, now accounting for a significant share of global cases and deaths as reported by the WHO.

  • Nearly 250,000 suspected cholera cases reported in Yemen.
  • 861 related deaths occurred as of December 1, 2024.
  • Yemen accounts for 35% of worldwide cholera cases and 18% of related deaths this year.
  • Inadequate access to clean water and poor sanitation exacerbates the crisis.
  • Yemen’s cholera response faces a $20 million funding gap.
  • Closure of treatment centers due to lack of funds, risking a repeat of past outbreaks.
  • 18.2 million people, nearly half of Yemen's population, require humanitarian assistance.
“The outbreak of waterborne diseases like cholera and acute watery diarrhoea imposes an additional burden on an already stressed health system facing multiple disease outbreaks.” - Arturo Pesigan, WHO Representative in Yemen

Immediate financial support is critical to prevent a worsening of the cholera outbreak in Yemen, which is already suffering from a long-standing humanitarian crisis.

item.title: New Zealand Says Highly Pathogenic H7N6 Avian Flu Has Been Contained; How Dangerous Is The Virus? - Times Now
item.description:
New Zealand Says Highly Pathogenic H7N6 Avian Flu Has Been Contained; How Dangerous Is The Virus?

Date: December 2023 | Source: Times Now

New Zealand has successfully contained the highly pathogenic H7N6 avian flu strain that affected a farm this month, following extensive testing and biosecurity measures.

  • The virus was detected on a chicken farm in Otago, South Island.
  • Confident of containment to the infected farm, all poultry exports have been temporarily suspended.
  • The farm is under a strict biosecurity lockdown while ensuring decontamination.
  • Low health risk for humans as the strain has never been found to infect people.
"We are on track to stamp out this disease,” said Mary van Andel, chief veterinary officer.

The New Zealand government is in communication with trade partners to manage poultry exports post-outbreak.

item.title: WHO reports cholera surge in Yemen: 250,000 suspected infections and 861 deaths as of Dec 1 - WION
item.description:
Cholera Surge in Yemen: 250,000 Suspected Cases and 861 Deaths Reported

Date: December 1, 2024 | Source: WHO

The WHO reports a dramatic increase in cholera cases in Yemen, with 250,000 suspected infections and 861 related deaths, highlighting the dire humanitarian crisis fueled by years of conflict and economic hardship.

  • Yemen has seen a 37% increase in cholera cases and a 27% rise in death rates from November 2023 to December 2024.
  • Cholera is exacerbated by factors like lack of clean water, poor sanitation, and limited healthcare access.
  • Financial constraints are critical, with a $20 million funding shortfall affecting treatment centers.
  • Over 18.2 million people in Yemen require humanitarian aid, with significant food insecurity impacting 17.6 million individuals.
“Waterborne diseases like cholera and acute watery diarrhea have added immense pressure on Yemen’s already struggling health system.” - Arturo Pesigan, WHO Representative in Yemen.

The situation in Yemen regarding cholera is deteriorating, and urgent funding and support are needed to prevent a catastrophe similar to the previous epidemic from 2017 to 2020.

item.title: Global disease resurgence in 2024 shows rising health threat - The Japan Times
item.description:
Global Disease Resurgence in 2024 Shows Rising Health Threat

Publication Date: 2024
Source: Airfinity

Some infectious diseases saw a huge surge in 2024, with the spread attributed, in part, to climate change, declining vaccination rates and the advent of new pathogen variants.

  • Dengue cases rose to over 13 million, a record high, with nearly 10,000 deaths globally.
  • Pertussis cases increased almost tenfold compared to 2023.
  • Other diseases on the rise include mpox, oropouche fever, and poliomyelitis.
  • The U.S. reported an unprecedented number of human avian influenza cases.
  • Climate change and extreme temperatures are contributing to the surge in disease spread.
  • Post-COVID pandemic immunization decline has led to a resurgence of diseases like measles.
  • Military conflicts disrupted vaccine campaigns, affecting polio resurgence in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
"The resurgence of preventable and climate-sensitive illnesses highlights the importance of adhering to preventive measures while advancing innovation to address diseases.” - Kristan Piroeva, Analyst at Airfinity

The findings point towards a critical need for global health coordination and the importance of preventive measures in addressing the increasing threats from infectious diseases.

item.title: 6 telltale signs you are low on Vitamin D and how to fix it - The Times of India
item.description:
6 Telltale Signs You Are Low on Vitamin D and How to Fix It

Publication Date: Not provided Source: Not provided

Vitamin D deficiency can silently affect well-being, often without noticeable symptoms until they disrupt daily routines. Many adults in the US are deficient in this crucial vitamin.

  • Bone and joint pain can indicate low Vitamin D levels.
  • Muscle weakness and spasms are common signs of deficiency.
  • Poor dental health, including cavities and oral diseases, may be linked to Vitamin D deficiency.
  • Hair loss has been associated with low levels of Vitamin D.
  • Unexplained fatigue can stem from insufficient Vitamin D.
  • A reduced appetite may indicate Vitamin D deficiency.
According to the NIH, around 1 in 4 US adults are deficient in this sunshine vitamin.

To address Vitamin D deficiency, individuals can increase sunlight exposure, consume vitamin D-rich food such as fatty fish, and be cautious with supplements.

item.title: Global disease resurgence in 2024 highlights growing health threat - Business Standard
item.description:
Global Disease Resurgence in 2024 Highlights Growing Health Threat

Publication Date: 2024 | Source: Airfinity Ltd.

The article discusses the alarming rise in infectious diseases in 2024, driven by climate change, decreasing vaccination rates, and new pathogen variants. It emphasizes the need for a coordinated global health response.

  • Record dengue cases exceed 13 million globally, surpassing last year's figures.
  • Significant increase in whooping cough cases.
  • Surge in mpox, oropouche fever, and poliomyelitis cases.
  • Unprecedented number of avian influenza cases in the US, with 61 infections reported.
  • Rwanda reports its first outbreak of Marburg virus.
  • Extreme climate conditions aiding the spread of vector-borne diseases.
  • Declining vaccination rates post-Covid-19 pandemic contributing to disease resurgence.
“The resurgence of preventable and climate-sensitive illnesses highlights the importance of adhering to preventive measures while advancing innovation to address diseases.” - Kristan Piroeva, Airfinity Analyst

Addressing the resurgence of infectious diseases requires bolstered vaccination efforts and global cooperation in health surveillance.

item.title: Simple tips for a healthier holiday season - The Indian Express
item.description:
Simple Tips for a Healthier Holiday Season

Date: Not provided Source: Not provided

During the festive season, people across the country come together to celebrate, with food—sweet, savory, and deep-fried—often taking center stage. While these treats are fine in moderation, we often indulge more than we should. But how much is too much, and are there ways to make our celebrations healthier?

  • Dr. Ritika Samaddar provides insights on maintaining health during the holiday.
  • Moderation is key when indulging in festive foods.
  • Tips suggested focus on healthier options.
“While these treats are fine in moderation, we often indulge more than we should.”

In conclusion, making small changes can lead to a healthier holiday season while still enjoying festive treats.

item.title: Bust fake news with Bangalore Mirror: Can fasting for 3 days shield you from rabies after a dog bite? - Bangalore Mirror
item.description:
Bust fake news with Bangalore Mirror: Can fasting for 3 days shield you from rabies after a dog bite?

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Bangalore Mirror

Claim: Fasting for three days after a dog bite allows the body to produce antibodies against rabies.

Fact: A 3-day fast cannot protect against rabies; timely vaccination is essential to prevent the disease.

The article clarifies a viral claim suggesting that fasting can substitute rabies vaccination after a dog bite. Experts emphasize that vaccination is critical while fasting has no scientific basis in preventing rabies.

  • The notion that fasting can protect against rabies is dismissed by health experts.
  • Doctors recommend immediate vaccination after any animal bite.
  • The Indian Academy of Pediatrics advises specific treatment protocols following animal bites.
  • Guidelines detail wound care and anti-rabies vaccination schedules critical for rabies prevention.
“There’s no scientific reasoning for such irrational management,” Dr. Salim Khan.

The article serves as an important reminder to seek proper medical treatment after a dog bite rather than relying on unfounded claims.

item.title: ​Autism spectrum disorder is a leading cause of non-fatal health burden, says study - The Times of India
item.description:
Study Identifies Autism Spectrum Disorder as Major Non-Fatal Health Burden

Publication Date: N/A

Source: N/A

This article discusses a recent study that has found autism spectrum disorder (ASD) to be one of the leading causes of non-fatal health burden worldwide, shedding light on the significant impact of the condition on individuals and society.

  • The study provides new statistics on the prevalence of autism spectrum disorder.
  • It highlights the significant impact of ASD on healthcare systems.
  • There's an emphasis on the need for increased support and resources for individuals with ASD.
“Understanding the health burden of autism is crucial for improving the quality of life for those affected.”

In conclusion, this study underscores the importance of addressing autism spectrum disorder as a critical public health issue that requires greater attention and resource allocation.

item.title: New Zealand’s Bird Flu Outbreak Should End Soon, Officials Say | Today News - Mint
item.description:
New Zealand’s Bird Flu Outbreak Should End Soon, Officials Say

Publication Date: December 2024 Source: Bloomberg

New Zealand officials announce that they have successfully contained a bird flu outbreak to a single location in Otago, with no further cases detected in linked farms.

  • Outbreak confirmed at an egg farm on December 1.
  • Exports of poultry products worth NZ$190 million were halted.
  • No positive results found in testing 4,300 samples from linked farms.
  • Officials express confidence in containing the virus.
  • Ongoing discussions with trading partners about export standards.
“It is a significant number of tests and gives us confidence that this virus has been contained to just the one property and that we are on track to stamp out this disease.” - Mary van Andel, Chief Veterinary Officer

As New Zealand moves towards resolving the outbreak, the Ministry for Primary Industries continues to collaborate with affected parties to ensure a safe return to poultry exports.

item.title: 7 everyday tips to keep your eyes healthy as you age - Mint
item.description:
7 Everyday Tips to Keep Your Eyes Healthy as You Age

Publication Date: December 23, 2024 | Source: Mint

As we age, our eyesight changes, leading to conditions like cataracts and glaucoma. Adopting simple habits can reduce risks and help maintain healthy vision in our later years.

  • Eat a balanced diet: Varied foods, especially deep yellow/green vegetables and Omega-3 rich fish like tuna and salmon, provide essential nutrients for eye health.
  • Wear sunglasses: Protect your eyes from sunlight exposure, which increases the risk of cataracts and macular degeneration.
  • Wash hands before touching your eyes: This prevents infections, especially for those who wear contact lenses.
  • Stop smoking: Smoking harms health by damaging blood vessels to the optic nerve, increasing the risk of cataracts.
  • Wear safety glasses: Protect your eyes during DIY projects to prevent injuries.
  • Get regular exercise: Regular exercise can prevent conditions that lead to chronic eye problems.
  • Get regular eye exams: Crucial for early detection of treatable eye problems, especially if there’s a family history of vision issues.
"Regular eye exams are crucial, especially if there's a family history of glaucoma or nearing 40. They help detect treatable eye problems early on."

In summary, maintaining eye health as you age involves simple lifestyle changes that can have a significant impact on your overall vision.

item.title: Good Wintertime Meals Are Warm, Healthy and Tasty - VOA Learning English
item.description:
Good Wintertime Meals Are Warm, Healthy and Tasty

Publication Date: Not specified Source: VOA Learning English

Winter is here, and it's time to embrace seasonal cooking that is nutritious and enjoyable.

  • Diet experts encourage experimenting with winter vegetables.
  • Citrus fruits, pumpkins, and root vegetables are in season.
  • Dried fruits and nuts add nutritional value to meals.
  • Soups, stews, and porridges are easy to prepare and freeze.
  • Gathering with friends and family for meals can combat winter isolation.
“Embrace the cold, embrace the winter and appreciate the bounty,” said Kristen Rasmussen.
“The benefit of it is that it's all contained,” said Linda Van Horn.

By utilizing seasonal produce and cooking methods, winter meals can be both healthy and comforting.
